Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use: Making and selling dyed fabric

loans.name: Florence Nyoh

texts.en:
Florence Nyoh Forbang is thirty-three years old, one of two wives in a polygamous marriage, and the mother of two young children. Like many in Cameroon, the greatest difficulties Florence faces are family death and poor health, stemming from poverty. Though young, she says that she suffered from a long period of sickness, although she has now recovered. Her son, too, was sick and required an operation, which Florence was able to afford only because of her membership in GHAPE. Lastly, Florence lost her sister, who left behind a sick child who Florence cared for until he too passed away.

Despite hardship, Florence has fought for her health and for the well-being of her family. She joined GHAPE in 2002 and has invested and repaid four loans. She runs a small general store and loans from GHAPE have helped to stock the store, and just last year, add a bar where she sells beer and other beverages. Her profits have helped her to improve her crop farm, start rearing pigs, buy a plot of land, and lay the foundation for an addition to her family compound. 

Florence now requests this loan to add to her various businesses. She plans to stock drinks in her bar, stock basic items in the store, add more piglets, buy bulk pig feed, and buy planting seeds for her farm. A chunk of the loan Florence wants to lend to her husband, who sells petrol. She says both of their businesses will succeed, because of hard work and location. The family lives right in the center of their village, so petrol sales are easy, and customers frequent her shop and bar. Florence will use the profits from her business to pay for her children’s school fees, take care of feeding her family, and care for her elderly grandmother.

She plans to repay her loan in 24 months and the first installment repayment will be due on the fourth month following disbursement.

loans.use: To stock drinks and food items; to buy seeds and piglets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase groundnuts, beans, and corn

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase corn seeds, beans, clearing and labor

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Born in 1961, Mama Beatrice was married to the late Pa Peter Zongcho.  While in her marital home, she successfully gave birth to seven children, two of whom are still below the age of fifteen years. Before she was able to access business capital, she felt incapable of assisting her husband to care for their family. These circumstances motivated her to join GHAPE in 2002. Since then, she has received and repaid five loans, totaling $550, from GHAPE.

Given a loan, she plans to buy yams and cassava seedlings for planting, and purchase fresh tomatoes and groundnuts in bulk for retail. She thinks her business will succeed because she already has a piece of land to cultivate and her many neighbors will provide a ready market for her fresh tomatoes and groundnuts. Moreover, she will help her neighbors, who previously had to trek long distances to acquire these basic commodities.       

Mama Beatrice plans to pay her loan in 24 months. The first installment repayment shall be made on the fourth month from the date of loan disbursement.

loans.use: To purchase cassava and yams seedlings, fresh tomatoes and groundnuts

loans.name: Arshad

texts.en: Arshad is single. His brother is pictured. He was born in 1987. He is an internally displaced person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, the Kalbadjar region, and he has settled in the Surakhani region. He has run this business for 4 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy more foodstuffs to grow his profits.

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Komak Credit Union - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia O. sells provisions, food products and soft drinks. She has been in business for the past three years, having learned the skills by herself. Lydia is 47-years-old and has six children.

She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years. This loan will enable her to buy more food products and soft drinks to increase her sales and grow her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and food products

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose J. sells electrical parts, a skill she learned from her husband over a four year period. She has owned the business since 2004. Rose is 42-years-old and has five children. She has been the secretary in her union for the past three years.

Rose is requesting a loan to buy more electrical parts which will enhance the prosperity of her business.

loans.use: To buy more electrical parts

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth A. lives in Ijaniki Lagos State Nigeria and owns a beauty salon. She has been in this business since 2001. Ruth is 40-years-old, married and has five children.

She is asking for this loan to buy more salon materials and also to introduce the sales of shoes and clothes in her salon as an additional business. She expresses her gratitude to all.

loans.use: To buy beauty salon products, shoes and clothing

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Basirat Ayinde

texts.en:
Basirat Ayinde O. sells garri from her house, She acquired this knowledge from her mother and has been in this business since 2000. She is 38-years-old, married and has four children. Basirat lives in sabo oniba, Lagos state.

Basirat Ayinde O. has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past three years and is requesting this loan to buy more garri and plantain to increase her sales.

loans.use: To buy more garri and plantain for resale

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah E. sells clothes and is also a fashion designer. She lives in Ajamgbadi, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Sarah has two apprentices and four sewing machines. She studied for 2-1/2 years prior to starting her business in 1998. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past three years and is requesting this loan to buy more fabric and another sewing machine for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and one sewing machine for the business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Nulu Nakakande’S Group

texts.en:
Nulu N. is a 42-year-old married mother of four children, ranging in age from 21 years to 10 months old.  She sells mukene (siver fish), a small fish sold by the scoopful and used to provide relatively inexpensive protein for meals.  Twice a week, she travels by truck from Kampala to Entebbe, about an hour drive away, to buy mukene from the market, leaving at 4:00 a.m.  She buys 8 large sacks at a time at 80,000/= each (Ugandan shillings, about $48 US), and brings them back to sell at the local market in smaller amounts.  Each sack nets a profit of about 20,000/= (about $12).  

Nulu and her group have previously received 8 loans from MCDT.  With this loan, Nulu would like to add inventory for her business.  The loan will also help her to pay school fees for her two middle children.

loans.use: To buy more fish

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ramota

texts.en:
Ramota B., 33, sells kitchen utensils, a business that she has had for the past eight years. She lives in shibiri, Lagos state, Nigeria with her husband and four children.

She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years. She is requesting a loan to buy more kitchen utensils for her business. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more kitchen utensils for resale

loans.name: Ayola

texts.en:
Ayola O. lives in shibiri ekunpa Lagos State Nigeria, where she sells wine, juice and soft drinks. She is 42-years-old, married and has four children.

Ayola learned how to run this business on her own and acquired the business ten years ago. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for three years. She is currently requesting a loan to increase her inventory of soft drinks, wine and juice for resale.

loans.use: To purchase more wine, juice and soft drinks for resale

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina U. is married. She is a small entrepreneur from Beregovo, and sells women’s and children’s clothing in the central city market. She started this business 5 years ago. Presently, Irina has about $2000 in inventory. His current income is about $400-600 each month. 

Irina’s business is self-sustainable. It has passed different formation stages: survival, growth and excellence in creating innovations and productivity. Today she is requesting a loan for 1500 Grivnas to re-stock her merchandise for summer season. This will help her generate additional income with new clothing products and increased sales. 


(Note: this is a short term “express” loan that will be paid back in one month.)

loans.use: To increase seasonal variety of inventory

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya F. is married with a one-year-old son. She lives in Korolyovo and sells bikes and spare parts in one of the local markets. She has been in this trade for 3 years. Currently, Nataliya has about $2000 in inventory. Her income is about $250-300 a month.  

Nataliya has passed many milestones on her road to success. She has learned to adapt with each
wave of change in the market world. Today she is a stable and confident entrepreneur with many bright ideas and plans for the future. One of her current plans is to increase her turnover capital with the help of a 1500 Grivna loan. 
 
(Note: this is a short term “express” loan that will be paid back in one month.)

loans.use: To increase turnover capital

loans.name: Bumi

texts.en: Bumi B. sells provisions, drinks and foodstuffs. Bumi is 40 years old and married with four children. The family lives in Shibiri, Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been in this business for the past seven years. She is a LAPO client.  She is requesting for the loan amount of $700 to buy more provisions, drinks and foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you to all that made this loan possible.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and foodstuffs for sales

loans.name: Koumba

texts.fr:
Mrs. Koumba Boité is the mother of four children (two girls and two boys), is 43 years old and lives with her husband, her co-wife, and their children in a polygamous family in Darsalam I neighborhood of Koutiala prefecture (near Sikasso). Selling food seasonings has been Koumba’s specialty for the last 15 years. She started this business very early in her life like most of the women of her generation, who didn’t have the opportunity to study. She has been making sales in the Darsalam I neighborhood where there isn’t a market and thus competitors are fewer. Sales are made from home, where products are spread out on a big table in the middle of the family compound. Her customers are mostly women who make purchases every day. She has had a relationship with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution for the last four years and has borrowed six loans (four group loans and two individual loans) that she has successfully repaid. The current loan will be used to purchase seasonings and vegetables in bulk (baskets of tomatoes, chilies, peppers, a case of spaghetti, two bags of salt, etc.). She anticipates making an average profit of 60,000 Francs CFA per month that she will use toward her family’s needs, to pay interest to Soro Yiriwaso, and to increase her capital. She plans to open a shop to sell seasonings in her neighborhood.

Translated from French by Liana Bianchi, Kiva Volunteer

Madame Koumba Boité est mère de 4 enfants (2 filles et 2 garçons), âgée de 43 ans et vit avec son mari , sa coépouse et leurs enfants dans une famille polygame au quartier Darsalam I de la Préfecture de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). La vente de condiments alimentaires est la spécialité de Koumba depuis 15 ans. Elle a commencé cette activité très tôt comme la plupart des femmes de sa génération n’ayant pas eu la chance de faire des études. Elle exerce cette activité dans le quartier Darsalam I ou il n’existe pas de marché par conséquent moins de concurrents. La vente se fait à domicile ou les produits sont étalés sur une grande table au milieu de la concession familiale. Sa clientèle est essentiellement composée de femmes qui effectuent les achats toute la journée. Elle est en relation avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis quatre ans et a obtenu 6 prêts (4 prêts de groupe et 2 prêts individuel) qui ont été correctement remboursés. Le prêt actuel servira à acquérir des condiments alimentaires et des légumes en quantité (des paniers de tomates, du piment, des poivres, un carton de vermicelles, 2 sacs de sels etc.…). Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 60 000 FCFA par mois qu’elle utilisera pour les besoins familiaux, pour payer les intérêts de SORO YIWASO et augmenter son capital. Elle envisage d’ouvrir une boutique de vente de condiments dans son quartier.

loans.use: Purchase seasonings and vegetables in bulk

loans.name: Deborah

texts.en:
Deborah A. lives in Imude, Lagos State, Nigeria where she sells provisions and kerosene. She is 40-years-old, married and has four children.

Deborah has owned this business for the past six years. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years and is now requesting a loan buy more kerosene, provisions and food stuffs to improve her business inventory and increase her sales and profit.

loans.use: To purchase more food, provisions and kerosene for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Moussa B. is a young shopkeeper who lives in the Grand Thiès neighborhood. He has been married for some time and manages a grocery store. He has already received a loan from Kiva, which he fully repaid. With this new loan, he would like to increase his supply of merchandise in order to earn a more consistent profit.

Translated from French by Kristina Jackson, Kiva Volunteer.

Moussa B. est un jeune commerçant qui vit au quartier Grand Thiès ; il est marié depuis quelques temps et gère une boutique de denrées alimentaires. Il a eu à bénéficier d'un prêt avec Kiva qu'il a remboursé avec succés. Avec ce prêt il veut renforcer son stock de marchandises afin de réaliser des bénéfices plus consistants.

loans.use: Increase his supply of merchandise

loans.name: Islamiat

texts.en:
Islamiat Y. sells clothes and is also a fashion designer and seamstress. She spent 2-1/2 years learning this skill. She is 24-years-old, single, and lives in Imude, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Islamiat has one sewing machine and two apprentices. She has been in business since 1996 and has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past three years. Islamiat is requesting this loan to buy more fabric and tailoring materials. She thanks you.

loans.use: To buy more fabric and more tailoring materials.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria S. sells dried and iced fish. A business that she has had for the past 28 years. She is 50-years-old and is married with five children. Maria lives in Imude, Lagos State, Nigeria. She has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years and is requesting a loan to buy more iced fish to increase her inventory.

loans.use: To purchase more iced fish for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Basirat

texts.en: Basirat B. sells jewellries and pillows in her community. She is 27-years-old and married with three children. She worked for another businessperson for five years before she started hers. Basirat has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years.  She is requesting for a loan of $350 to buy additional jewellries and pillows to sale.

loans.use: To purchase additional jewelry items and pillows for resale

loans.name: Endurance

texts.en:
Endurance I. sells over-the-counter drugs to local villagers. She studied for three years before opening her business in 2006. Endurance has been borrowing from LAPO Microfinance for the past two years.

She is 26-years-old and is married with two children. She lives in shibiri, Lagos State, Nigeria. She is requesting a loan to buy more drugs and provisions for maximum business growth and for profit maximization.

loans.use: To buy more over-the-counter drugs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Okeke

texts.en:
Okeke A. is 35-years-old and is married with three children. She lives in ojo Igbede, Lagos state, Nigeria.

She sells televisions and stereos in the Alaba international market. Okeke has been in this business since 1997 after three months of training in the business. She is requesting a loan to buy more televisions and stereos so that she can improve in her business inventory, thereby increasing her sales and profit margin.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventories of televisions and stereos for resale

loans.name: Happiness

texts.en:
Happiness N. lives in ojo Igbede, Lagos State, Nigeria. Happiness is 32-years-old and is married with four children.

She sells electronic components. This is a skill that she learned in three months and has been in this business for the past three years. She is requesting a loan to buy more electronic components for resale . She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more electronic components for resale

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria Enehlives in Alaba. Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 33-years-old and is married with six children.

Victoria sells electronics at the Alaba Int’l market. She studied this field for two years and has been in this business for the past ten years. She is requesting the loan to purchase more electronics for sale in her store. She says thank you.

loans.use: To buy more electronics for resale

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Safina Nakalema’S Group

texts.en:
Safina N. is a 26-year-old married mother of 5 children, ranging in age from 3 to 13 years old.  She is the leader of a group of four women taking out their 8th loan from MCDT.  She was able to start her clothing business with a loan from MCDT. 
Safina describes herself as a “hard working woman.”  She has a kiosk in her neighborhood of Mulago where she sells clothing for small children seven days a week from 6 in the morning until 10 at night.  Each week, and sometimes twice a week, she re-stocks her inventory by buying clothing from the market at Kikumba.  She reports that about 30 people a day come to her shop—mostly men.  Sundays are particularly busy. 
With this new loan, Safina will be able to complete a goal of building a house.  She has already purchased a plot about 3.5 km (2 mi) away.  With the loan, she will be able to start construction on the house and eventually not need to pay rent.

loans.use: To build a house

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Micro Credit Development Trust SACCO (MCDT) - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Eze

texts.en:
Eze C. is 25-years-old, married and has four children. She lives in Alaba, Lagos State, Nigeria.

Eze sells electronics at the Alaba Int’l market. She studied this field for three months and has been actively selling electronics since 2003. She is requesting a loan to buy more electronics products to sell in her shop. She says thank you to all.

loans.use: To buy more electronics

loans.name: Rafoat

texts.ru:
Rafoat has more than 27 years of business experience. She began trading in small goods and has gradually branched out. Rafoat is 52 years old, is married, and has 4 children. She sells fabric as well as making traditional printed cloth, which is popular among young people. These prints give dresses an unusual look. It is possible to order a printed cloth from her collection of drawings or to custom order an original drawing. Having learned about Кiva, she has decided to apply for a loan to increase her assortment of goods and to purchase fabrics.

Translated from Russian by Melissa, Kiva Volunteer.

Рафоат имеет опыт деятельности более 27 лет. Начинала она с мелкой торговли, постепенно ее деятельность расширялась. Рафоат 52 года, она замужем и имеет 4 детей. Кроме торговли тканями она еще занимается набивкой рисунков на тканях, что пользуется популярностью среди молодежи. Эти рисунки придают платьям оригинальный вид. У нее можно сделать набивку не только из ее коллекции рисунков, но и заказать свой оригинальный рисунок. Узнав о КИВА она решила обратиться за займом, который собирается использовать для увеличения ассортимента своих товаров и закупа тканей.

loans.use: to increase inventory

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Ms. Fatoumata C. is 38 years old, lives with her three children and her husband in a monogamous family in the village of Dialakoroba (Kati prefecture) in the Koulikoro region.

Very early on, she started making money due to not being able to attend school. After having worked at several things without success, she decided to become specialized in the commerce of various articles. She works in this business throughout the year and gets her supplies twice a month in Bamako, the capital of the Republic of Mali.

In order to obtain financial resources to enlarge her commercial business, she decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso program with which she has had an association for six years now. She is on her fourth individual loan, and all the previous ones have been repaid without a problem.

With this loan, she intends to buy 15 to 20 sacks of foodstuffs and condiments at the grand marketplace of Bamako. This monthly provision will be stocked in her home and sold by displaying them in front of her door to customers who are made up of women from her village and from neighboring villages. She is a specialist in having available the essential condiments that customers generally need. The goods are nicely arranged and packaged on the table. Sale are made at the retail level by request. She intends to realize a profit of 60,000 francs CFA per month, which will enable her to help cover family expenses, to pay the loan interest, and to invest the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Madame Fatoumata C. est agée 38 ans , vit avec ses 3 enfants, et son époux dans une famille monogame dans le village de Dialakoroba Préfecture de Kati Région de Koulikoro.

Elle a commencé très tot les activités génératrices de revenus faute de n’avoir pas pu faire l’école .Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, elle décida de se spécialiser dans le commerce d’articles divers . Elle mène cette activité durant toute l’année et s’approvisionne deux fois par mois à Bamako capitale de la République du Mali.

Afin d’obtenir des ressources financières pour élagir son activité commerciale ,elle décida d’intégrer le programme de Soro Yiriwaso avec lequel elle est en rélation depuis maitenant 6 ans. Elle est à son quatrième pret individuel et tous les précedents ont été remboursés sans difficultés. Avec ce prêt, elle compte acheter 15 à 20 sacs de denrées et condiments alimentaires au grand marché de Bamako. Cette provision mensuelle sera stockée chez elle afin de les vendre sur des étales devant sa porte à une clientèle constituée de femmes de son village et des villages environnants. Elle a la spécialité de disposer de l’essentiel des condiments alimentaires dont les clints ont généralement besoin. Les produits sont bien disposés et bien conditionnés sur une table. La vente se fait au détail à la demande. Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice de 60.000 F CFA par mois qui lui permettra de contribuer aux dépenses de sa famille payer les intérêts du prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.

loans.use: To buy a large amount of condiments

loans.name: Kibrohon

texts.ru: Киброхон 62 года, воспитывает 5 детей. Занимается она куплей продажей сухофруктов на ентральном рынке города Исфара. Ее основная деятельность - покупка косточек от абрикосов, их раскалывание и продажа зернышек от них. Рынок сухофруктов разделяется на куплю продажу абрикосов, косточек от них и еще зернышек от косточек. Многие семьи в Исфаринском районе работают в этой сфере и этим зарабатывают себе на жизнь. Кроме Киброхон ей помогает ее старшая дочь. Рано утором они выезжают на окрестные рынки, покупают там косточки. привозят их к себе домой и потом в течении дня раскалывают их с помощью специального приспособления. После сортировки зернышек их раскладывают по мешкам и пролают на следующем базаре. Полученная прибыль идет на содержание семьи и частично идет на расширение бизнеса. Узнав о КИВА Киброхон решила обратиться

loans.use: для увеличения оборотного капитала

loans.name: Kibrohon

texts.ru:
Kibrohon is 62 years old and is raising 5 children. She buys and sells dried fruit in the central market of the city of Isfara. She mostly buys apricot kernels, splits them, and sells the nut within. The dried fruit market is divided into the buying and selling of apricots, their kernels, and nuts from the kernels. Many families in the Isfara District make their living by working in this sphere. Kibrohon is helped in this work by her oldest daughter. Early in the morning they leave for the neighboring markets to buy apricot kernels. They bring them home where during the day they they split them, using a special device. After sorting the nuts they divide them into bags and take them to the next market. Their profit goes to supporting the family and partly to expanding the business. Once she found out about Kiva, Kibrohon decided to apply for a loan to expand her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Киброхон 62 года, воспитывает 5 детей. Занимается она куплей продажей сухофруктов на ентральном рынке города Исфара. Ее основная деятельность - покупка косточек от абрикосов, их раскалывание и продажа зернышек от них. Рынок сухофруктов разделяется на куплю продажу абрикосов, косточек от них и еще зернышек от косточек. Многие семьи в Исфаринском районе работают в этой сфере и этим зарабатывают себе на жизнь. Кроме Киброхон ей помогает ее старшая дочь. Рано утором они выезжают на окрестные рынки, покупают там косточки. привозят их к себе домой и потом в течении дня раскалывают их с помощью специального приспособления. После сортировки зернышек их раскладывают по мешкам и пролают на следующем базаре. Полученная прибыль идет на содержание семьи и частично идет на расширение бизнеса. Узнав о КИВА Киброхон решила обратиться за займом для расширения своей деятельности.

loans.use: Increase operating capital

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
The women of the Benkadi group are married and have on average an age of 22 and four children. They live in polygamous households and reside in the village of Banankoro (Kati prefecture) in the Koulikoro region. The women of the Benkadi group are united professionally and by friendship, and they have all developed in the sector of small-scale commerce in various articles (soap, tea, cigarettes, catering, etc.)

For the most part, they get their supplies locally, in the village, from wholesalers (daily or weekly) and make their sales from displays at the marketplace of the same village, located along the axis road linking Bamako to the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire. Their customers, essentially composed of women, make their purchases throughout the day, sometimes even at night at their homes.

This group of Benkadi women is on its first collaboration with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. It intends to use this loan to buy a few boxes of soap, tea, packs of cigarettes, a large amount of condiments, and sacks of rice and of millet. They hope to realize a monthly profit of 15,000 francs CFA each.

The group aspires to establish an EIG (Economic Interest Group) in order to organize their business better and to defend their interests better.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont mariées avec une moyenne d’age de 22 ans et 4 enfants .Elles vivent dans des foyers polygames, et résident dans le village de Banankoro Préfecture de Kati Région de Koulikoro.

Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont unies par des relations d’amitié et professionnelles et évoluent toutes dans le secteur du petit commerce d’articles divers (savon, thé, cigarettes, restauration etc.).

Elles s’approvisionnent très généralement sur place au village auprès des grossistes (quotidiennement ou hebdomadairement) et vendent sur des étales au marché du même village situé sur l’axe routier reliant Bamako à la République de la Cote D’ivoire. Leur clientèle, essentiellement composée de femmes fait des achats durant toute la journée, même quelque fois la nuit à domicile.

Ce groupe de femmes Benkadi est à sa première collaboration avec l’Institution de micro finance Soro Yiriwaso. Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt quelques cartons de savons, de thé, des cartouches de cigarettes, une importante quantité de condiments alimentaires, des sacs de riz et de mil. Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 15.000 CFA chacune. Le groupe ambitionne de mettre en place un GIE (Groupement d’Intérêt Economique) afin de mieux organiser leurs activités et mieux défendre leurs intérêts.

loans.use: To buy various articles

loans.name: Hadiyahon

texts.ru:
Hadiyahon teaches in a public school in the village of Kul'kent in the Isfara District of Tajikistan. She is 40 years old, married, and is raising 3 children. She and her husband make enough money to support the family, but now that her oldest child is growing up and has finished high school, he should start attending a university. Hadiyahon cannot afford to pay the whole tuition up-front, and so when she found out about the possibility of receiving a loan through Kiva, she decided to approach us about one. She would like to thank in advance all who finance her application. 

 Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer.

Хадияхон работает учителем в общеобразовательной школе в джамоате Кулькент Исфаринского района. Ей 40 лет, она замужем и воспитывает 3 детей. Она и муж зарабатывают достаточно для содержания семьи, но ее старший ребенок подрос и после окончания средней общеобразовательной школы должен поступить в высшее образовательное учреждение. Оплатить сразу всю стоимость обучения Хадияхон не имеет возможности и поэтому узнав о возможности полчения займа в КИВА решила обратиться сюда за займом.  Она заранее благодарна всем кто финансирует ее заявку.

NOTE:  Due to religious reasons, Mrs. Y. requested that her face picture not be visible on the Kiva website.  Inasmuch, one may observe the Kiva logo in place over her face per her request.

loans.use: University Tuition

loans.name: Luisa

texts.es:
Luisa works serving customers in her small shop each day, and she has been doing so for 5 years. She started working with a small amount of capital and over time she has seen her business grow. She would like to make her shop bigger and see it grow. She would also like her last 3 kids to keep studying. Your help with Luisa's loan is very important for her continued development.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Luisa trabaja diariamente en la atención D. su pequeña tienda, lo viene haciendo desD. hace ya 5 años, ella comenzó trabajando con un pequeño capital y con el tiempo ha visto crecer su negocio, tiene como proyecto agrandar su tienda y crecer ella misma. Su deseo también es que sus 3 últimos hijos sigan estudiando. Tu apoyo en el préstamo D. Doña Luisa es D. suma importancia para que continue con su desarrollo.

loans.use: To make the shop bigger and for her kids' education/Ampliación de su tienda y estudios de sus menores hijos.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Danaya group are mostly married women living in traditional extended families. They have on average three children and an average age of 32. They reside in the village of Banankoro (Kati prefecture) in the Koulikoro region.

The members of the group Danaya are linked to each other by ties of family, community, and friendship. To obtain financial resources to fill their fund of capital, they decided to collaborate with the Soro Yiriwaso loan program, with which the Danaya group is on its first loan. After a series of four training sessions regarding community living and good business management, they obtained a loan in the end. They all work in small-scale commerce of various articles (soap, undergarments, condiments, etc.) at the marketplace in town. Each day, they get their supplies in bulk in Bamako, the capital of Mali. The sales are retail sales and are made at the marketplace by displaying the good or often by going door-to-door .

With this loan, they expect to realize a profit of 15,000 to 20,000 francs CFA each month. The women of the Danaya group hope to increase their profits substantially but also to diversify their sources of supplies.

Translated from French by Daniel Kuey, Kiva volunteer

Les membres du groupe Danaya sont en majorité des femmes mariées vivant dans des familles traditionnelles élargies et ayant en moyenne 3 enfants et 32 ans d’age. elles résident dans le village de Banankoro Préfecture de Kati Région de Koulikoro.

Les membres du groupe Danaya sont liés entre elles par des liens de consanguinité, de voisinage et d’amitié. Pour obtenir des ressources financières afin de completer leur capital, elles décidèrent de collaborer avec le programme de crédit Soro Yiriwaso avec qui le groupe Danaya est à son premier prêt . Après une série de quatre formations portant sur la vie associative, la bonne gestion des activités économiques elles ont finalement obtenu un prêt. Elles mènent toutes le petit commerce d’articles divers ( savon, lingerie, condiments alimentaires etc.) au marché de leur localité. Elles s’approvisionnent hebdomadairement en gros à Bamako la capitale du Mali. Les ventes sont effectuées au detail au marché sur des étales et souvent de facon ambulante.

Elles comptent réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice moyen de 15.000 FCFA à 20.000 FCFA par mois. Les femmes du groupe Danaya espèrent augmenter substantiellement leurs profits mais aussi diversifier leurs sources d’approvisionnement.

loans.use: To buy various articles for small-scale commerce

loans.name: Sarah Namuyomba `s Group

texts.en:
N. Sarah is a 45-year-old widow with 9 children ranging in age from 4 ½ to 27 years old.  The youngest seven are all in school.  She lives and works in Mulago, an urban neighborhood of Kampala near the big city hospital. 
For the past 10 years, Sarah has been dealing in charcoal.  Every two weeks she travels to Luweero, a village about two hours away, to buy 50-100 sacks of charcoal.  After arranging to have it transported back by truck, she sells it from a kabanda, a kind of local kiosk, in smaller increments to people who live in the neighborhood, making a profit on her investment. 
Sarah has been a member of MCDT since 2003 and has received at least 7 previous loans.  With this new loan, she will continue to expand her charcoal business, purchasing more charcoal to sell.  Her eventual goal is to buy a plot of land and build a house.

loans.use: To buy more inventory of coal

loans.name: Zenaida Rebeca

texts.es:
Zenaida is a hard-working woman who toils tirelessly in her small brick factory, where she has worked for 20 years. Her wish is to earn income for the wellbeing of her 6 children, who have motivated her continuously. Currently Zenaida is supporting the studies for 4 of her children. Her wish is to be able to produce a greater number of bricks, taking advantage of the time in the year when profits are higher. She will use the requested loan money to purchase a greater amount of sawdust, an important ingredient for making bricks.

Translated from Spanish by Todd M. Anderson

Zenaida es una mujer muy trabajadora, ella labora incansablemente en su pequeña fábrica de ladrillos, donde viene trabajando hace 20 años, su deseo de generar ingresos para el bienestar de sus 6 hijos, la han motivado incansablemente. En la actualidad, Zenaida vela por los estudios de sus 4 menores hijos, su deseo es poder producir mayor cantidad de ladrillos aprovechando esta época del año en que recibe mejores ganancias, con el dinero solicitado podrá invertir en mayor cantidad de aserrín, insumo importante para la fabricación de sus ladrillos.

loans.use: Purchase of important materials to continue her business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Microfinanzas PRISMA - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Kankelentigui Group

texts.fr:
The members of the Kankéléntigui group are married women with, on average, 5 children and are approximately 38 years old. They live in polygamous families with their husbands, children and other wives in the village of Banankoro in the Kati / Koulikoro region. The group met through their neighbourhood, families or friends. They all have various small businesses selling different staples (condiments, food, fruit and vegetables, clothing for children, etc.). The majority of the group members buy supplies once a month in Bamako, or in the village itself. However, food and condiment supplies are best supplied daily or weekly according to the season. In order to obtain additional resources for their business, the Kankéléntigui group members decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso Micro finance institution which has just granted their first loan. They would like to each benefit from a monthly income of 13.000 to 16.000 FCFA. The diversification of their activities is a permanent concern of the group members.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Translator

Les membres du groupe Kankéléntigui sont des femmes mariées ayant en moyenne 38 ans et 5 enfants .Elles vivent dans des familles polygames avec époux, enfants et coépouses dans le village de Banankoro Préfecture de Kati Région de Koulikoro. Elles se sont connues par des liens de voisinage, d’amitié et familial. Elles exercent toutes dans le secteur du commerce d’articles divers (condiments, alimentaires, fruits et légumes, habillements pour enfants etc.…). La majorité des membres du groupe s’approvisionnent une fois par mois à Bamako, et quelques fois sur place au village. Mais s’agissant des condiments alimentaires elle se fait quotidiennement ou hebdomadairement selon les saisons. Pour obtenir des ressources financières complémentaires les membres de groupe Kankéléntigui décidèrent de nouer une relation avec l’Institution de Micro finance Soro Yiriwaso qui vient de leur octroyer leur premier prêt. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice de 13.000 à 16.000 F CFA par mois par membre. La diversification des activités est un souci permanent des membres du groupe.

loans.use: Purchase of different items for small business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Soro Yiriwaso, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)
